page.title: 14A Talk given by Resident "B"
page.content: A lady, who has lived in the village all her life, came to talk to us about the area that we live in. Her father was headmaster of our school from 1921 until 1955. His wages for the year were Â£216 and farm labourers earned at the very most, Â£1 a week. Just before World War II broke out, five bus loads of evacuees came to the village. One of these was a Jewish boy from Austria called Arnold and when a bomb dropped on the nurses house opposite the school, Arnold said, "There the nurses house wasn't." She also told us that bombs dropped on the cricket pitch and an American bomber crashed down the Chelmsford Road, a bit further than the Hunters Meet. At school they didn't have just milk - they had Horlicks and if the children were good they were allowed to stir it and miss their arithmetic!
